title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to:

Differentiate between Observational Studies and Experiments.
Identify the components of an experiment: Factors, Levels, and Treatments.
Apply the four principles of experimental design.
Recognize confounding variables and explain how randomization resolves them.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
1. Observational Studies
Definition: Researchers observe choices or outcomes without assigning treatments.

Retrospective: Looking at past data (e.g., examining medical records).
Prospective: Following subjects into the future (e.g., tracking a cohort).


Key Takeaway: Observational studies can show association, but they cannot prove causation.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
2. Experimental Terminology
To prove causation, we need an Experiment, where we manipulate conditions.

Response Variable: What we measure (e.g., Tomato weight).
Factors: The explanatory variables we manipulate (e.g., Fertilizer, Water).
Levels: The specific values chosen for a factor.

Fertilizer Levels: None, Brand A, Brand B
Water Levels: 500ml, 1000ml

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Defining Treatments
A Treatment is a specific combination of the levels of each factor assigned to a subject.
Example: Growing Tomatoes
Combining the factors from the previous slide (3 Fertilizer levels \(\times\) 2 Water levels) creates 6 Distinct Treatments:



None + 500ml
None + 1000ml
Brand A + 500ml



Brand A + 1000ml
Brand B + 500ml
Brand B + 1000ml

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
3. The Four Principles of Design
To create a valid experiment, we must:

Control: Make conditions as similar as possible for all groups.
Randomize: Equalize the effects of unknown variation.
Replicate: Use enough subjects so differences aren’t just anecdotes.
Block: Group similar subjects together before randomizing.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Diagrams & Blinding
Diagrams: Visual maps starting from the Subject Pool \(\rightarrow\) Random Assignment \(\rightarrow\) Treatments \(\rightarrow\) Response.
Blinding: Hiding the treatment assignment to reduce bias. * Placebo: A fake treatment to measure the “Placebo Effect.” * Double-blind: Neither subject nor evaluator knows the assignment.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
4. Confounding
The Enemy of Inference.
When the levels of one factor are associated with the levels of another factor, we cannot separate their effects.

Example: Testing a new teaching method only in the morning. Is it the method or the time of day?
Randomization is the cure for confounding.

title: Experiments and Observational Studies
text:
Summary (Review of Objectives)

Obs vs. Exp: Only Experiments can prove causation; Observational studies only show trends.
Components: Remember that Treatments are the specific combinations of Factor Levels.
The Big Four: Valid experiments must Control, Randomize, Replicate, and Block.
Confounding: We Randomize to ensure that confounding variables are spread equally across groups.
